page.title: 13Abbots Down and Jews Wood
page.content: Abbots Down and Jews Wood are mostly deciduous trees. The trees are largely{sweet chestnut and beech trees. In the distance the trees were conifers. The conifers were young fir trees. The fir trees were fenced off from the rest of the wood. The {tracks}were wide because tractors used them to clear the wood out. However there seemed to be far more tracks in the wood than were needed. From hoof marks we could tell that the wood is also used for{riding.} The wood had been looked after when the chestnut wood was taken out to use for fencing: we could tell because of the coppicing which had taken place. There are fallen trees and plenty of undergrowth, and some muddy and treacherous tracks, so in 1985 it seems that the wood needs looking after a bit better.
